chapter.htmlHeader: How common is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Coeliac disease is under-diagnosed, and it is estimated that for every person diagnosed, seven to eight people remain undiagnosed [Mooney, 2014b]. The prevalence data for coeliac disease varies according to the population studied, sample size, and disease definition [West, 2014; Singh, 2018].

  • The prevalence of coeliac disease has increased over the past 50 years [Lebwohl, 2015; Al-Toma, 2019].
    • A large-scale European population screening study (n = 29,212 adults and children) from Finland, Italy, Germany, and the UK reported a prevalence of around 1%, using serological testing and inclusion of people who were previously diagnosed [Mustalahti, 2010].
      • The study noted that prevalence rates varied significantly in adults across different countries, being highest in Finland and lowest in Germany.
    • A European Society for the Study of Coeliac Disease guideline notes [Al-Toma, 2019]:
      • The increase in new cases may be partially due to improved diagnostic tools, and through screening of people considered to be at high risk.
      • In western countries, the prevalence is around 1% with serological screening of the general population, and 0.6% in histologically confirmed cases.
      • It affects all age groups, including the elderly, with more than 70% of new cases diagnosed in people over 20 years of age.
    • A large UK population-based primary care study (1990–2011) found a total of 9087 incident cases of coeliac disease, equating to an overall incidence rate of 13.8 per 100,000 person-years. The incidence rate increased four-fold over the study period, from 5.2 per 100,000 to 19.1 per 100,000 person-years, and there were large regional variations in prevalence [West, 2014].
      • About 3 in 10,000 children under 5 years of age were diagnosed.
      • About 4 in 1000 adults over the age of 70 years were diagnosed.
      • The increase in incidence was theorized to be due to improvements in the identification and diagnosis of coeliac disease over the study period.
  • Various studies have found a female preponderance in cases of coeliac disease.
    • A meta-analysis of 96 studies found [Singh, 2018]:
      • The pooled global prevalence was 1.4% (n = 275,818) based on serology testing.
      • The pooled global prevalence was 0.7% (n = 138,792) based on biopsy testing.
      • The prevalence was higher in females than in males (0.6% compared with 0.4%).
    • A meta-analysis of 50 studies found [King, 2020]:
      • The global pooled female incidence was 17.4 per 100,000 person-years, compared with 7.8 in males.
      • The global incidence in children was 21.3 per 100,000 person-years, compared with 12.9 in adults.
      • The incidence of coeliac disease has increased by 7.5% per year over the past several decades.
    • A US study found coeliac disease is more frequently diagnosed in women than in men with a ratio between 1.5:1 and 2:1, and the incidence rates increased with age and over time [Murray, 2003].
  • Expert opinion in a review article notes that coeliac disease can occur at any age from early childhood to old age, with two peaks of onset; one shortly after weaning with gluten in the first 2 years of life, and the other in the second or third decades of life [Caio, 2019].
